facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 147 of 1959 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 147 of 1959. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 21, 1959 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Revision No. 503 of 1958 arising out of the judgment and order dated March 27, 1958, of the Sessions Judge, Allahabad, in Criminal Appeal No. 745 of 1957.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated July 21, 1959 of Allahabad High Court in Criminal Revision No. 503 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 21, 1959 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Revision No. 503 of 1958 arising out of the judgment and order dated March 27, 1958, of the Sessions Judge, Allahabad, in Criminal Appeal No. 745 of 1957.

facts.text: Arising out of judgment and order dated March 27, 1958 of Sessions Judge Allahabad in Criminal Appeal No. 745 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated March 27, 1958, of the Sessions Judge, Allahabad, in Criminal Appeal No. 745 of 1957. B. Agarwala and K. P. Gupta, for the appellant. C. Mathur and C. P. Lal, for the respondent. 1960. December 16.

facts.text: Appellant Sarjoo Prasad convicted by P. M. Agra Magistrate First Class Allahabad under s.7 read with s.16 Prevention of Food Adulteration Act 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH, J.-The appellant, Sarjoo Prasad was convicted by P. M. Agra, Magistrate First Class, Allahabad of an offence under s. 7 read with s. 16 of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954 37 of 1954 hereinafter referred to as the Act-and in view of a previous conviction for a similar offence was sentenced to suffer rigorous imprisonment for one year and to pay a fine of Rs. 2,000.

facts.text: Sarjoo Prasad sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for one year and fine Rs. 2000 due to previous conviction.

anchor.surface_text: Magistrate First Class, Allahabad of an offence under s. 7 read with s. 16 of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954 37 of 1954 hereinafter referred to as the Act-and in view of a previous conviction for a similar offence was sentenced to suffer rigorous imprisonment for one year and to pay a fine of Rs. 2,000. The conviction and sentence were confirmed in appeal by the Court of Session at Allahabad and by the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad in revision.

facts.text: Conviction and sentence confirmed by Sessions Court Allahabad and Allahabad High Court in revision.

anchor.surface_text: was sentenced to suffer rigorous imprisonment for one year and to pay a fine of Rs. 2,000. The conviction and sentence were confirmed in appeal by the Court of Session at Allahabad and by the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad in revision. The appellant has appealed to this Court with special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Supreme Court with special leave under Art. 136 Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The conviction and sentence were confirmed in appeal by the Court of Session at Allahabad and by the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad in revision. The appellant has appealed to this Court with special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Sarjoo Prasad was employee of Thakur Din who carries business at 92-C Mirganj Allahabad as vendor of edible oils and provisions.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has appealed to this Court with special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution. The appellant was an employee of one Thakur Din who carries on business at 92-C, Mirganj, Allahabad as a vendor of edible oils and provisions.

facts.text: On September 22 1956 Food Inspector Allahabad Municipality purchased sample of mustard oil from appellant exposed for sale in shop.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was an employee of one Thakur Din who carries on business at 92-C, Mirganj, Allahabad as a vendor of edible oils and provisions. On September 22, 1956, a Food Inspector of the Allahabad Municipality purchased from the appellant a sample of mustard oil exposed for sale in the shop which on analysis was found to be adulterated with linseed oil.

facts.text: Sample of mustard oil on analysis found adulterated with linseed oil.

anchor.surface_text: purchased from the appellant a sample of mustard oil exposed for sale in the shop which on analysis was found to be adulterated with linseed oil. Thakur Din and the appellant were prosecuted in the court of the First Class Magistrate, Allahabad for selling adulterated food.

facts.text: Thakur Din and appellant prosecuted in court of First Class Magistrate Allahabad for selling adulterated food.

anchor.surface_text: which on analysis was found to be adulterated with linseed oil. Thakur Din and the appellant were prosecuted in the court of the First Class Magistrate, Allahabad for selling adulterated food. The Magistrate convicted Thakur Din and the appellant and sentenced Thakur Din to pay a fine of Rs. 200 and the appellant to suffer rigorous imprisonment for one year and to pay a fine of Rs. 2,000.

facts.text: Magistrate convicted Thakur Din fine Rs. 200 and appellant RI one year fine Rs. 2000.

anchor.surface_text: Thakur Din and the appellant were prosecuted in the court of the First Class Magistrate, Allahabad for selling adulterated food. The Magistrate convicted Thakur Din and the appellant and sentenced Thakur Din to pay a fine of Rs. 200 and the appellant to suffer rigorous imprisonment for one year and to pay a fine of Rs. 2,000.

facts.text: Appellant pleaded mustard oil delivered to Food Inspector was not meant for sale; plea disbelieved by Trial Magistrate, confirmed by Sessions and High Court.

anchor.surface_text: That the mustard oil sold by the appellant was adulterated has not been challenged in this appeal. The appellants plea that the mustard oil delivered to the Food Inspector was not meant for sale was disbelieved by the Trial Magistrate and that view has been confirmed by the Court of Session and the High Court.

facts.text: Mustard oil sold by appellant was adulterated; not challenged in appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The material part of s. 16 1  provides If any person,  a  whether by himself or by any person on his behalf-----sells-----any article of food in contraventionof the provisions of this Act or he shall be punishable That the mustard oil sold by the appellant was adulterated has not been challenged in this appeal.

facts.text: Previous conviction of Sarjoo Prasad shown by extract dated April 7 1956 of judgment in criminal case No. 208 of 1956 by P. N. Jauhari Magistrate F-Class Allahabad; offence adulteration mustard oil, fine Rs. 80.

anchor.surface_text: There is no substance in the contention that the conviction of the appellant was not for a second offence committed by him under the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act. The prosecutor produced before the court an extract dated April 7, 1956 of a judgment in criminal case No. 208 of 1956 which showed that one Sarjoo Prasad had been convicted by P. N. Jauhari, Magistrate F-Class, Allahabad of the offence of adulteration of mustard oil and sentenced to pay a fine of Rs. 80.

facts.text: Details in previous conviction extract match appellant: name, father's name, residence.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecutor produced before the court an extract dated April 7, 1956 of a judgment in criminal case No. 208 of 1956 which showed that one Sarjoo Prasad had been convicted by P. N. Jauhari, Magistrate F-Class, Allahabad of the offence of adulteration of mustard oil and sentenced to pay a fine of Rs. 80. In the view of the Magistrate, the extract related to the appellant. The name of the person convicted and his fathers name and residence were identical with the name of the appellant,

facts.text: In memorandum of appeal to Sessions Court, not contended that previous conviction was of other person.

anchor.surface_text: his fathers name and his residence. All the details given in the extract tallied with the description of the appellant. In the memorandum of appeal filed to the Court of Session challenging the conviction recorded by the Magistrate First Class, it was not contended that the person convicted in the earlier case was some person other than the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant was merely employee of Thakur Din; not shown he made profit from transaction.

anchor.surface_text: In the memorandum of appeal filed to the Court of Session challenging the conviction recorded by the Magistrate First Class, it was not contended that the person convicted in the earlier case was some person other than the appellant. But the appellant was merely an employee of Thakur Din. It is not shown that he made himself any profit out of the transaction.

facts.text: Thakur Din sentenced to fine Rs. 200 only.

anchor.surface_text: But the appellant was merely an employee of Thakur Din. It is not shown that he made himself any profit out of the transaction. Thakur Din has been sentenced to pay a fine of Rs. 200 only.

facts.text: Supreme Court reduces appellant's sentence to three months rigorous imprisonment and remits fine.

anchor.surface_text: The offence committed by the appellant is a repetition of a similar offence committed by him a few months earlier, but we think that having regard to all the circumstances, this is a case in which there are special and adequate reasons which would justify imposition of a penalty less than the minimum prescribed by s. 16 ii  of the Act. We reduce the sentence to imprisonment to three months and we remit the fine.

holdings.text: Every person, be he an employer or an agent, is prohibited from selling adulterated food and infringement of the prohibition is by s. 16 penalised; servants are liable under ss. 7/16 without proof of mens rea.

anchor.surface_text: The expression person has number been defined in the Act and in the companytext in which that expression occurs, it prima facie includes every one who sell adulterated food. By the companylocation of the expression, numberperson shall himself or by any person on his behalf, the employer alone is number prohibited. The intention of the Legislature is plain. Every person, be he an employer or an agent is prohibited from selling adulterated food and infringement of the prohibition is by s. 16 penalised.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain textual interpretation of 'person' in ss.7/16 includes agents/servants; strict liability for public health per s.19; rejects requirement of mens rea; overrules contrary Madras HC view in Re S. Moses.

holdings.text: The previous conviction relates to the appellant, constituting a second offence under the Act.
